short_instructions.https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/: Can you help me catch the naughty pig? Stack a couple of `move forward` blocks below the `when run` block and press "Run".
This pig is ruffling my feathers. Help me get to him!
Trace the path and lead me to the silly pig. Avoid TNT or feathers will fly!
Guide me to the green evilness! (Watch out for TNT)
Keep calm and help me find the bad pig. Otherwise I might get angry!
Guide me to the green evilness! (Watch out for TNT)
Get me to the pig!
Guide me to the green evilness! (Watch out for TNT)
Guide me to the green evilness! (Watch out for TNT)
_"The pig is hiding! Can you help me find a way around?"_
Sometimes there is more than one way to solve the same problem. Sometimes it's faster to go backwards than it is to go forwards!
Hi, I'm an artist. You can write code to make me draw almost anything. Use a few blocks to make me draw over the grey lines in the picture. (Each line is 100 pixels long)
This house has a half-finished wall. Each side is 100, but the half-finished wall is only 50. Complete the wall.

The red hat is 100 pixels tall. Finish drawing a black hat that is 70 pixels shorter. 
(Note: The width of each hat is 50 pixels.)
The jump block moves the artist without drawing. Draw the dashed line using both the `jump forward` and `move forward` blocks. Each line is 50 pixels long.
Help me complete the house for this cat.
This house needs a roof! Draw the triangle.  Hint: all three sides are the same length.
Finish this kite
Finish drawing the last set of windows on the school so that everyone in class can see outside. The sides of each square window pane are 25 pixels long.

Complete the rooms for each of the animals by splitting the rectangle into 2 equal-sized squares. The rectangle is 200 pixels wide and 100 pixels tall. There are many different ways to solve this puzzle, so have some fun!
Free-play! Draw anything you'd like.
Assessment: Finish drawing the last tooth. It is 25 pixels wide and 25 pixels tall.
Draw rooms for each of the animals. There are many different ways to solve this puzzle, so have some fun. The shortest possible solution is 6 blocks, but use as many as you like!
_Help me paint the yellow lines on this road!_
Can you get me to the pig using 5 of the same kind of blocks?
Can you get to the pig by creating a loop that uses only one `move forward` block inside of a `repeat`?
Get me to the pig! You can only use one move forward block this time
In this puzzle, two `repeat` loops will help you get to the pig with the fewest number of blocks!
Can you figure out the fastest way to get me to the pig?
Loops even work with more than one block inside!  Can you loop this sequence to get the zombie to the sunflower?
Use what you learned to get me to the sunflower!

Get me to the sunflower using the fewest blocks possible!  

Try using one `repeat` loop inside of another to cut down on the amount of code you need.

Let's take this to another level! 
Use loops to get me to the sunflower with the fewest loops possible.
Get me to the sunflower using the fewest number of blocks possible!
Get me to the sunflower using the fewest blocks possible!
Assessment:  Get me to the sunflower using only 5 blocks!
Now Scrat wants to try using loops to find his acorn!
Get all of the treasure!
Let's draw this robot's head! Can you make a square with sides that are 100 pixels?

Here is the same puzzle that we just solved, but this time, we can only use one `move forward` block and one `turn` block this time.

Can you use a `repeat` to solve this puzzle?
Try to figure out what happens if you run this code (or just press "Run" and try it). Next, repeat the code enough times to complete the drawing!
How many degrees are in a circle?  Loop the blocks to create a circle of colors.
Give the stop sign a border by making an octagon with 100 pixels sides.

Create a circle to finish the eyeball!

If the artist turns 1 degree with each loop, how many times do you need to repeat the code to draw a circle? 180? 360? 500?
Draw a simple V (where both sides are 50 pixels) to complete the arrow.
Now let's connect a bunch of V's together in a loop.
Rebuild the code from the last puzzle, but this time, add a left turn of 30 degrees inside the loop. Now, repeat it 24 times instead of 8.
Draw a diamond with sides of 100 pixels.

We are going to start you with some code (in grey) to make one diamond. 

Loop the grey code to create a fun pattern!
Play around with the code for the diamond and see what other patterns you can make. Try changing how many degrees you turn and how many times you loop.
Now, draw anything you like!
Hi, I'm a bee. Can you help me collect the nectar from these flowers?
This time, use a loop to gather all of the nectar.
Use a `repeat` loop to collect all of the nectar.
Now use the `repeat` block to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
What a beautiful field of flowers!   Help the bee visit each one.  Can you find a way to do it with fewer than 7 blocks?

How many times can loops help you in this puzzle?  

Loops are your friend! Use a few of them to complete this puzzle with the fewest blocks possible.

Those flowers look tasty!

Collect nectar from each of the flowers using the fewest blocks possible.
Collect all the nectar and make all of the honey using the fewest blocks possible.
Collect nectar from each flower and make honey at each honeycomb using the fewest blocks possible.

Such a busy bee!

Help bee collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey with the fewest blocks possible.

The shape of this path is different than the others. 

Can you collect all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible?
Can you find the quickest way for the bee to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey?
Assessment: Collect all of the nectar using the fewest blocks possible.
Collect all of the corn.
Collect all of the lettuce. Avoid the trees and fields!
These blocks are really bugging me. Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.

Can you find the problem here?
Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.

Ooh, this one stings!

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.
These blocks are really bugging me. Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.

That flower looks tasty! 

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.  You can now use both run and step.

What a sweet challenge!

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.
Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.

So many beautiful flowers!

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.

"Bee" patient with this one!

You will need to fix a couple of things in this program to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.

This puzzle is making me loopy! 
Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.

Assessment:  Now it's time to show what you know!

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
Look carefully! Can you collect all _10_ pieces of treasure?
There are 20 pieces of treasure to be found. Collect at least half to finish this challenge!
This hat should only be 50 pixels wide.  Can you fix it?

This code for the cat's whiskers is wrong. 

Fix this code to draw whiskers that are all the same length.

My boat has a hole! 

What do you need to fix to make the ends meet?

The code that we have for the leg and foot is wrong. 

Can you fix it?

Looks like I'm sitting on a chair that’s missing a leg!

Edit the code to draw the last leg.

Looks like the C in code is drawn backwards!

Can you make it look like a C again?

My teacher says that I should finish what I start!

Help me finish my pinwheel. Can you figure out what's wrong?

Something is off!

The code for this stem is wrong. Can you figure out how to get the artist to trace the stem the right way?

The direction pad on my game controller is too narrow. 

Can you make it wider by 10 pixels?

Try running the code first to see what's wrong.

My snowflake is falling apart!

Can you figure out what's going wrong?

Assessment: Why does this square end up being 75 pixels too small on each side?  

Where does the code go wrong?

I'm a hungry bee! 
Help me collect all of the nectar from the flowers using the fewest number of blocks.

Look at all of that nectar!

Help me collect the nectar and make the honey using as few blocks as you can.

Be careful not to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any. 
You must first check if the nectar is equal to 1 using the `if nectar` block.
Check this flower with an "if" block to see if there is any nectar available.
Collect nectar from each flower only if it has any.
This field has red and purple flowers. Red flowers have a known nectar amount, but purple flower nectar is unknown. Collect all the nectar.
Collect all the nectar from each flower.

I wonder what's out there!

Help me fly around the yard and collect nectar only from the flowers that have some.
Help me find all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible!

There's a lot happening here!

Use what you've learned to collect all of the nectar and then make the honey.

Let's put everything together!

Use what you've learned to help me collect nectar only from flowers that have it, using as few blocks as possible.  Don't forget to make honey at the end.

This stair step pattern should look familiar.  

Can you collect nectar only from the flowers that have some, using as few blocks as possible?
Assessment: Collect all of the nectar. Be careful not to try to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any.
Collect all of the nectar or make all the honey.
Collect all of the nectar or make all the honey.
Attach a block to the "when click" block, then press "Run". Click or tap the screen to move Flappy to the target.
Now we've added some ground.  Attach a block to the "when hit the ground" block.  Your code needs to 'END GAME' when Flappy crashes.
The "when run" block allows you to run code when your game starts.  Try setting the level speed and flapping to the target.

Flappy will fly through obstacles unless you write code to make him crash. Attach a block to the "when hit an obstacle" block. Your code needs to 'END GAME' when Flappy crashes into the first set of pipes.
Let's add a scoreboard, and count points when Flappy makes it past obstacles. Add to the "when pass an obstacle" block, and then score a point by flying Flappy through the first set of pipes.
See if you can still score a point after making Flappy flap either a smaller or larger amount.
Next, try changing the scene by attaching another block to the "when run" block.
You can set visuals anytime, not just when the game starts. Try setting a RANDOM scene when other events happen, for example, when passing an obstacle.
To mix things up, when hitting an obstacle, instead of ending the game try setting the score back to 0.
Create your own Flappy game. You can change all the visuals and all the rules, even the gravity. When you're done, click Finish to let friends try your game on their phones.
Put a `repeat` block around this whole stack of code to draw the pattern.

Now loop the triangle 6 times. 

After each triangle, you'll need to turn 60 degrees before drawing the next.

You'll need to loop the triangle 12 times to draw this pattern. 

Divide the number of degrees in a circle (360) by the number of shapes you're drawing (12) to figure out how far to turn after each shape.

Loop this diamond 12 times to draw a flower!

Note: We'll use the same angle to loop 12 diamonds as we did for 12 triangles.  
How much do you need to turn after each shape?

Fill in this building's windows using a nested loop. 

The windows are 20 pixels long and 20 pixels apart.

This dinosaur has 8 spikes running up its tail.
Each spike is 30 pixels long. Loop the triangle 8 times, but make sure to jump forward after each one!

Loop this triangle 10 times to draw the sun. 

You'll need to move and turn after each triangle. 

You can figure out how much to turn by dividing the number of degrees in a circle by the number of triangles that make it up.

Now let's add some grass to our picture. 

Each tuft of grass is 50 pixels apart.

We'll finish this picture by adding our flower. 

Loop the diamond 12 times to draw the flower.
Loop this code 12 times to complete the pattern.
Loop this code 4 times to complete the pattern, turn 90 degrees after each circle.
Loop this code 12 times to complete the curls.
Free play, draw something cool with nested loops.
Can you figure out how to make a picture like this?
Can you figure out how to make a picture like this?

long_instructions.https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/:
Can you help me catch the naughty pig? 

Stack a couple of `move forward` blocks below the `when run` block and press "Run".
_"The pig is hiding! Can you help me find a way around?"_
Sometimes there is more than one way to solve the same problem. Sometimes it's faster to go backwards than it is to go forwards!
Hi, I'm an artist. You can write code to make me draw almost anything. Use a few blocks to make me draw over the grey lines in the picture. (Each line is 100 pixels long)
This house has a half-finished wall. Each side is 100, but the half-finished wall is only 50. Complete the wall.

The red hat is 100 pixels tall. Finish drawing a black hat that is 70 pixels shorter. 

_(Note: The width of each hat is 50 pixels.)_
The jump block moves the artist without drawing. Draw the dashed line using both the `jump forward` and `move forward` blocks. Each line is 50 pixels long.
Help me complete the house for this cat.
This house needs a roof! Draw the triangle. Hint: all three sides are the same length.
Finish this kite

Finish drawing the last set of windows on the school so that everyone in class can see outside. 

The sides of each square window pane are 25 pixels long.

Time to build a barn!

Make the rooms for each animal by splitting the barn into 2 equal-sized squares. 

Hint: The rectangle is 200 pixels wide and 100 pixels tall.

There are many different ways to solve this puzzle.
Free-play! Draw anything you'd like.
**Assessment:** Finish drawing the last tooth. It is 25 pixels wide and 25 pixels tall.
Draw rooms for each of the animals. There are many different ways to solve this puzzle, so have some fun!
_Help me paint the yellow lines on this road!_

Suddenly, a magical block appears!  With the `repeat` block, you can loop code over and over.

Can you get to the pig by creating a loop that uses only one `move forward` block inside of a `repeat`?
Get me to the pig! You can only use one `move forward` block this time
In this puzzle, two `repeat` loops will help you get to the pig with the fewest number of blocks!

Get me to the sunflower using the fewest blocks possible!  

Try using one `repeat` loop inside of another to cut down on the amount of code you need.

Let's take this to another level! 

Use loops to get me to the sunflower with the fewest loops possible.
**Assessment:**  Get me to the sunflower using only 5 blocks!

_"Let's hunt for treasure - using loops!"_

Help the collector by debugging this code. Get all of the treasure!
Let's draw this robot's head! Can you make a square with sides that are 100 pixels?

Here is the same puzzle that we just solved, but this time, we can only use one `move forward` block and one `turn` block this time.

Can you use a `repeat` to solve this puzzle?

Try to figure out what happens if you run this code (or just press "Run" and try it). 

Next, repeat the code enough times to complete the drawing!

How many degrees are in a circle?  

Loop the blocks to create a circle of colors.
Give the stop sign a border by making an octagon with 100 pixels sides.

Draw a simple V (where both sides are 50 pixels) to complete the arrow.
Now let's connect a bunch of V's together in a loop.

Time to make something snazzy! 

Rebuild the code from the last puzzle, but this time, add a left turn of 30 degrees inside the loop. Now, repeat it 24 times instead of 8.
Draw a diamond with sides of 100 pixels.

We are going to start you with some code (in grey) to make one diamond. 

Loop the grey code to create a fun pattern!

Play around with the code for the diamond and see what other patterns you can make. 

Try changing how many degrees you turn and how many times you loop.
Now, draw anything you like!
Use a `repeat` loop to collect all of the nectar.
Now use the `repeat` block to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.

What a beautiful field of flowers!   

Help the bee visit each one.

Can you find a way to do it with fewer than 7 blocks?

Loops are your friend! Use a few of them to complete this puzzle with the fewest blocks possible.

Those flowers look tasty!

Collect nectar from each of the flowers using the fewest blocks possible.

Help Bee collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey with the fewest blocks possible.

Collect all of the lettuce. Avoid the trees and fields!

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.

**Assessment:**  Now it's time to show what you know!

This hat should only be 50 pixels wide. Can you fix it?

Fix this code to draw whiskers that are all the same length.

What do you need to fix to make the ends meet?

Can you fix it?

Edit the code to draw the last leg.

Looks like the C in code is drawn backwards!

Can you make it look like a C again?

My teacher says that I should finish what I start!

Help me finish my pinwheel. Can you figure out what's wrong?

Something is off!

The direction pad on my game controller is too narrow.

**Assessment:** 
Why does this square end up being 75 pixels too small on each side?  

Where does the code go wrong?

I'm a hungry bee! 

Help me collect all of the nectar from the flowers using the fewest number of blocks.

Look at all of that nectar!

Help me collect the nectar and make the honey using as few blocks as you can.

These magic purple flowers change!

Each time you try the puzzle, purple flowers can have either 1 nectar or none at all...but you won't know the number until you run the code! 

Be careful not to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any. 
You must first check if the nectar is equal to 1 using the `if nectar` block.

I wonder what's out there!

Help me fly around the yard and collect nectar only from the flowers that have some.

There's a lot happening here!

Use what you've learned to collect all of the nectar and then make the honey.

Let's put everything together!

Use what you've learned to help me collect nectar only from flowers that have it, using as few blocks as possible.

Don't forget to make honey at the end.

This stair step pattern should look familiar.  

Can you collect nectar only from the flowers that have some, using as few blocks as possible?

**Assessment:** Collect all of the nectar.  
Be careful not to try to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any.
Collect all of the nectar and make all the honey. You can collect all of the nectar in one flower by using the `while nectar > 0` loop.
Collect all of the nectar or make all the honey. You can only collect nectar from flowers and make honey from honeycombs. Check any space to see if there is a flower or honeycomb.
You've used loops to draw shapes before, but now we're going to put loops inside of other loops! Put a `repeat` block around this whole stack of code to draw the pattern.

Now loop the triangle 6 times. 

After each triangle, you'll need to turn 60 degrees before drawing the next.

You'll need to loop your triangle 12 times to draw this pattern. 

Divide the number of degrees in a circle (360) by the number of shapes you're drawing (12) to figure out how far to turn after each shape.

Loop this diamond 12 times to draw a flower!

Note: We'll use the same angle to loop 12 diamonds as we did for 12 triangles.  
How much do you need to turn after each shape?

Fill in this building's windows using a nested loop. 

The windows are 20 pixels long and 20 pixels apart.

This dinosaur has 8 spikes running up its tail.

Each spike is 30 pixels long. 

Loop the triangle 8 times, but make sure to jump forward after each one!

Loop this triangle 10 times to draw the sun. 

You'll need to move and turn after each triangle. 

You can figure out how much to turn by dividing the number of degrees in a circle by the number of triangles that make it up.

Now let's add some grass to our picture. 

Each tuft of grass is 50 pixels apart.

We'll finish this picture by adding our flower. 

Loop the diamond 12 times to draw the flower.
Loop this code 12 times to complete the pattern.
Loop this code 4 times to complete the pattern, turn 90 degrees after each circle.
Loop this code 12 times to complete the curls.
Free play, draw something cool with nested loops.

Can you figure out how to make a picture like this?

-   Both shapes have **50 pixel sides.**
-   The _octagons_ are made with **45 degree** turns.
-   The _triangles_ are made with **120 degree** turns.

Can you figure out how to make a picture like this?

-   The first inner loop should make an octagon.
-   The second inner loop should make a hexagon.
-   The third inner loop should make a square.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Maze_1_a: To use a `move forward` block, drag it from the toolbar area out into the workspace and connect it to the `when run` block.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Maze_6_a: There are two ways to solve this puzzle!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_maze_programming_challenge2_a: _If you send me backwards, be extra careful that I turn the correct way!_
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_maze_programming_challenge2_b: The shortest solution use only 5 blocks, but it uses the `repeat` block!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_1_new_a: If you use the block to have me `move forward by 100 pixels`, I will draw a line automatically.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_1_new_b: Having trouble turning the corner? Use the `turn right 90 degrees` block.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_2_new_a: The artist doesn't seem to be pointing in the correct direction. Can you make them turn first before drawing the line?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_3new_a: What is 100-70?  Based on the story problem, that's how tall the hat needs to be!
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_3new_b: The artist doesn't seem to be pointing in the correct direction. Can you make them turn first before drawing the line?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_4_a: To finish the house, all we need to do is draw a square!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_6_a: To make those little angles, you have to turn _farther_ each time than you did with the square.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_6_b: Since I'm already facing to the right, it's easiest to start by moving forward, then make left turns to create the triangle.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_6_c: Each side of the triangle is the same length as each side of the square...100 pixels!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_9_a: This diamond is really just a square on its side

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_7_a: The easiest way to solve this puzzle is to draw the first square and end with the artist pointing down before starting your second square.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_8_a: If you cut 200 in half, how many pixels wide does each square need to be?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_artist_prog_challenge1_a: The rectangle is 200 pixels wide and 100 pixels tall.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_artist_prog_challenge2_a:
You can put commands inside `repeat` block to loop them over and over. Try it!

<xml>
  
          <block type="controls_repeat">
            <title name="TIMES">6</title>
            <statement name="DO">
              <block type="draw_move_by_constant_dropdown">
                <title name="DIR">moveForward</title>
                <title name="VALUE" config="25,50,100,150,200,300">25</title>
                <next>
                  <block type="jump_by_constant_dropdown">
                    <title name="DIR">jumpForward</title>
                    <title name="VALUE" config="25,50,100,150,200,300">25</title>
                  </block>
                </next>
              </block>
              </statement></block></xml>

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Maze_16_a: If the pattern is hard to see, try coding it all out first and see what things repeat over and over before you put the loops in.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Maze_16_b:
To put lots of blocks inside a `repeat` loop, just drag a loop out into the workspace, then drag all of the blocks from the starting program inside of it.  

Connect it all back to the `when run` block and you're good to go!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Maze_Loops_17_a: If the pattern is hard to see, try coding it all out first and see what things repeat over and over before you put the loops in.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Maze_Loops_17_b: Did the starting code get deleted?  Click `start over` to get it back!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Maze_Loops_18_a: If the pattern is hard to see, try coding it all out first and see what things repeat over and over before you put the loops in.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Maze_Loops_19_a: If you are stuck, try writing out the code without loops first and looking for patterns.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Maze_Loops_19_b: Putting one repeat loop inside of another can help decrease the number of blocks used.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Maze_Loops_20_a: Look for a stair-step pattern in this maze to find where a loop can be used.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Maze_Loops_21_a: If you are having trouble finding the stair-step pattern, try covering the blocked paths with your finger.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_maze_loops_challenge1_a: Think about this path as being three different pieces. Each one has a pattern you can repeat.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_maze_loops_challenge1_b: In between each `repeat` block, you will need to `turn left` or `turn right` to get ready Scrat for the next pattern.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_maze_loops_challenge1_c:
If you make it this far, you just need to `turn left` then `move forward` a few times. Don't give up!

[][0]

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_maze_loops_challenge2_a: The original code would work great - if there was only one piece of treasure in each pile!
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_maze_loops_challenge2_b: Use loops so you don't run out of `collect` blocks!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.4-5_Artist_4_a:
There are 360 degrees in a circle! 

That's how many times you need to repeat this code (turning 1 degree at a time) before the circle is done!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_11_a: Having trouble with the angles? You need to go 360 degrees in 8 turns.  What is 360/8?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_12_a: There are 360 degrees in a circle, so if the artist turns 1 degree each time through the loop, he'll need to go through 360 times.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Loops_New_9_a: The artist needs to turn 45 degrees to the right before he starts drawing.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Loops_New_9_b: This V is really just half of a square.  What would the code be to draw half of a square?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Loops_New_11_a:
Remember that the code from the last puzzle was:

<xml>
  <block type="when_run" deletable="false" movable="false">
    <next>
      <block type="controls_repeat">
        <title name="TIMES">8</title>
        <statement name="DO">
          <block type="draw_colour" inline="true">
            <value name="COLOUR">
              <block type="colour_random"/>
            </value>
            <next>
              <block type="draw_turn_by_constant_dropdown">
                <title name="DIR">turnRight</title>
                <title name="VALUE" config="45,60,90,120,180">45</title>
                <next>
                  <block type="draw_move_by_constant">
                    <title name="DIR">moveForward</title>
                    <title name="VALUE">50</title>
                    <next>
                      <block type="draw_turn_by_constant_dropdown">
                        <title name="DIR">turnLeft</title>
                        <title name="VALUE" config="45,60,90,120,180">90</title>
                        <next>
                          <block type="draw_move_by_constant">
                            <title name="DIR">moveForward</title>
                            <title name="VALUE">50</title>
                          </block>
                        </next>
                      </block>
                    </next>
                  </block>
                </next>
              </block>
            </next>
          </block>
        </statement>
      </block>
    </next>
  </block>
</xml>
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Loops_New_11_b: Your new turn should go at the **end** of the code inside the loop.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist Loops_New_12_a: Before starting the diamond, the artist needs to turn left by 60 degrees to get on the right path.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist Loops_New_12_b: After the artist goes forward 100 pixels, he will need to turn right 120 degrees to make the sharp corner.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist Loops_New_12_c: The artist will need to turn right only 60 degrees to create a wide corner.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Loops_New_13_a:
At the end of each diamond, the artist is already facing the right direction to start the next one.  

Because of this, we don't need to add an extra `turn left by` block before we start again.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Loops_New_13_b:
To make each diamond, the artist needs to:   

-   move
-   turn right 120 degrees
-   move
-   turn right 60 degrees  

Then do it all again!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Loops_3B_a: You will need two different `repeat` loops, one after the other.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Loops_7_a: The first action will be a turn, rather than a move.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Loops_7_b: If you can't quite picture the loop from the beginning, try coding it out the long way, then look for a pattern.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Loops_4A_a: The first action will be a turn, rather than a move.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Loops_4A_b: The last piece of the program can be finished by writing code at the end of your program outside of your loop.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Loops_4A_c: If you can't spot the loops yet, try coding it out the long way first, then see what you can combine into a `repeat` loop at the end.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Loops_2_a: You should end up with four blocks inside your loop.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Loops_3_a: You should have 6 blocks inside your loop.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Loops_4_a: You should end up with five blocks inside your loop.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Loops_5_a: If you can't spot the blocks to put inside `repeat` right away, start by coding out each move and look for a pattern.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Loops_6_a: If you can't tell what should go into the `repeat` loop, try dragging blocks out one by one and see if you can find a pattern.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Loops_6_b: There should be 6 blocks inside your `repeat` loop when you're done.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_harvester_loops_challenge1_a: Don't even think about try about trying this without loops!
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_harvester_loops_challenge1_b: You can repeat `move forward` and `pick corn` as many times as you need to, then `turn right` at each corner.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_harvester_loops_challenge1_c:
The best way to collect the first four corn uses a `repeat` block inside of another `repeat` block. You can use this pattern for the rest of the puzzle too!

<xml>
  <block type="when_run" deletable="false" movable="false">
    <next>
      <block type="controls_repeat">
        <title name="TIMES">2</title>
        <statement name="DO">
          <block type="controls_repeat">
            <title name="TIMES">2</title>
            <statement name="DO">
              <block type="maze_move">
                <title name="DIR">moveForward</title>
                <next>
                  <block type="harvester_corn"/>
                </next>
              </block>
            </statement>
            <next>
              <block type="maze_turn">
                <title name="DIR">turnRight</title>
              </block>
            </next>
          </block>
        </statement>
        </block></next></block></xml>

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_harvester_loops_challenge2_a: One way to solve this looks like a zig-zag. Another way looks like a spiral! There are lots of different solutions to a puzzle like this. Be persistent!
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_harvester_loops_challenge2_b: You can repeat `move forward` and `pick lettuce` as many times as you need to, then turn at each corner.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseC_harvester_loops_challenge2_c:
This zig-zag pattern can be repeated twice to finish the puzzle with just 20 blocks!

This spiral pattern can be coded with just 18 blocks!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Debugging_2_a: Once you find and fix the incorrect block, do you see any patterns that could be made more simple using a `repeat` loop?

You can use the `collect` command more often to collect the extra treasure.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Debugging_2_a: Hint: Each whisker is 75 pixels long.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Debugging_3_a: One of the turns is 15 degrees too small.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Debugging_3_b: If the program runs too fast to see what's happening, try slowing it down with the slider.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Debugging_7_a: What happens if you have the artist move or jump backward after he draws the first line?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Debugging_8_a:
How many times did my shape repeat?

How many times _should_ the shape repeat?

Where can you change that in the program?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Debugging_9_a: The artist needs to turn 60 degrees farther left before starting to draw!
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Debugging_9_b: You don't need to add another block to get the full turn, just add 60 degrees to the `turn left` block that's already there!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Debugging_10_a: Remember, you want the control panel 10 pixels _wider_...so be sure to **add** 10 to whatever number you change.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Debugging_10_b:
**Trial and error is perfectly fine here!**  

Start by changing one number at a time.   

Which numbers do what?  

If you get too lost, just click "Start over" and your code will be reset.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Conditionals_3_a: The code will be shortest if you use a loop each time you move forward, another loop to gather nectar, and another one to make honey.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Conditionals_6_a: Remember: Purple flowers change between 0 and 1 nectar when you run your program!

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Conditionals_14_a: Having a hard time figuring out how to get the blocks down?  Try treating the red flower exactly the same as a purple flower!
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Conditionals_14_b: If the red flower were purple, could you figure out how to use an extra `repeat` loop to cut down on code?
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Conditionals_14_c:
Try breaking this up into two separate chunks:

[][0]

1.  Gather nectar 3 times

    -   Move forward 5 times
    -   Check to see if nectar, if so: get it
    -   Turn left

2.  Make honey
    -   Move forward one time
    -   Make two honey

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Bee_Conditionals_15_a: Remember: Purple flowers only have either 0 or 1 nectar and they can change each time you run the program.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseD_bee_conditionals_challenge1_b:
Just like the `if at flower` blocks, the code inside a `while nectar > 0` will only run if the bee is at a flower. The main differences is that the code inside will run repetitively until there is no nectar left.  Try this pattern:

<xml>  <block type="bee_whileNectarAmount">
    <title name="ARG1">nectarRemaining</title>
    <title name="OP">></title>
    <title name="ARG2">0</title>                    <statement name="DO">
                      <block type="maze_nectar"/>
                    </statement>
  </block></xml>

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseD_bee_conditionals_challenge1_a:
Can you find a path that reaches every flower and honeycomb without hitting any trees? The best path is a spiral.

**You can solve this without ever turning left.**
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseD_bee_conditionals_challenge1_b: In this puzzle, each space could have a flower, a honey comb, or nothing.  That means you can repeat your `if/else` conditional at each square.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Nested_Loops_1_a: Remember to put all of the grey blocks inside of your loop.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Nested_Loops_3_b: Remember to put all of the grey code and your turn block inside of a loop.

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.2-3_Artist_Nested_Loops_5_a:
Try using the `jump forward` block to get from the top of one square to the place where you will start the next. 

If your squares are 20 pixels tall and they are 20 pixels apart, how far do you need to jump?

How far should you turn in each loop?

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseD_artist_nestedLoops_challenge1_a: Start by making a nested loop to create four octagons. Turn 45 degrees to make the octagon. Jump, then turn 90 degrees after each one.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseD_artist_nestedLoops_challenge1_b: Add code to draw a triangle inside of your nested loop. Use 120 degree turns for your triangle.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseD_artist_nestedLoops_challenge1_c:
Use a nested loop:

-   Repeat 8 times
    -   draw an octagon
    -   draw a triangle
    -   jump forward 50 pixels
    -   turn right by 90 degrees

https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseD_artist_nestedLoops_challenge2_a: To draw a regular octagon, the artist needs to turn 45 degrees 8 times.
https://studio.code.org/s/course2/stage/.courseD_artist_nestedLoops_challenge2_b: To draw a square, the artist needs to turn 90 degrees 4 times.
